question: Which part of the Milky Way contains mostly old stars?

content.source_1: The Milky Way is a barred spiral galaxy composed of distinct structural regions, including a roughly spherical stellar halo that surrounds the disk and bulge.
content.source_2: The Milky Way’s stellar halo is dominated by very old, metal-poor Population II stars and shows little or no current star formation.
content.source_3: The Galactic bulge is the Milky Way’s dense, central spheroidal region surrounding the Galactic center.
content.source_4: Observations indicate the Milky Way’s bulge is overwhelmingly old (typical ages around 10 billion years), with only a minor younger component.
content.source_5: The Galactic disk and spiral arms host most of the Milky Way’s ongoing star formation and many young stars.
content.source_6: The Milky Way’s globular clusters—ancient star systems—are largely members of the stellar halo, tracing its old, metal-poor population.
